Line 6: Line 6:      
<!--various usages-->In [[English language|English]], the word ''[[wikt:en:love|love]]'' can refer to a variety of different feelings, states, and attitudes, ranging from generic [[pleasure]] ("I loved that meal") to intense [[interpersonal attraction]] ("I love my partner"). "Love" can also refer specifically to the passionate desire and intimacy of [[romance (love)|romantic love]], to the [[sex]]ual love of [[eros (concept)|eros]] (cf. [[Greek words for love]]), to the emotional closeness of [[familial love|familial]] love, or to the [[platonic love]] that defines [[friendship]],<ref name="PlatonicSchool">{{cite book |last=Kristeller |first=Paul Oskar |title=Renaissance Thought and the Arts: Collected Essays |publisher=Princeton University |year=1980 |isbn=0-691-02010-8}}</ref>
 
<!--various usages-->In [[English language|English]], the word ''[[wikt:en:love|love]]'' can refer to a variety of different feelings, states, and attitudes, ranging from generic [[pleasure]] ("I loved that meal") to intense [[interpersonal attraction]] ("I love my partner"). "Love" can also refer specifically to the passionate desire and intimacy of [[romance (love)|romantic love]], to the [[sex]]ual love of [[eros (concept)|eros]] (cf. [[Greek words for love]]), to the emotional closeness of [[familial love|familial]] love, or to the [[platonic love]] that defines [[friendship]],<ref name="PlatonicSchool">{{cite book |last=Kristeller |first=Paul Oskar |title=Renaissance Thought and the Arts: Collected Essays |publisher=Princeton University |year=1980 |isbn=0-691-02010-8}}</ref>
−
to the profound [[Henosis|oneness]] or devotion of [[Religious views on love|religious love]].
+
to the profound [[Henosis|oneness]] or devotion of [[Religious views on love|religious love]].<ref name="Gita">{{cite book |last= Mascaró |first=Juan |title=The Bhagavad Gita |publisher=Penguin Classics |year=2003 |isbn=0-140-44918-3}} (J. Mascaró, translator)</ref>
−
<ref name="Gita">{{cite book |last= Mascaró |first=Juan |title=The Bhagavad Gita |publisher=Penguin Classics |year=2003 |isbn=0-140-44918-3}} (J. Mascaró, translator)</ref>
   
This diversity of uses and meanings, combined with the complexity of the feelings involved, makes love unusually difficult to consistently define, even compared to other emotional states.
